example, in Margery’s scripts, the teacher refers to the radio
audience as "students”. Since a large part of that audience
vill be adults, many of whom will probably be teachers, I refer
to them as "our listeners" or merely as "all of you” or some such
phrase# Probably the scripts wtfould be adjusted so that this
practice is the same in all the scripts, and you people and Dr.
Goodell should know which is best.
A similar inconsistency is Margery's use of "radio teacher*
to refer to the teacher, as against my use of the word "teacher”
alone•
A somewhat different inconsistency is the role we have given
Donna. In my scripts, the teacher may ask the listeners to repeat
something after Donna, but Donna herself never asks them. In my
opinion it unduly complicates the lesson to have two people telling
the listeners what to do. Margery apparently feels otherwise (we
have not discussed this), because I see that she has Donna telling
the listeners to repeat things after her now and then. This is
another point that you and Dr. Goodell could probably settle better
than we can.
One convention that both Margery and I have used is PAUSE...
REPEAT.. .PAUSE. This always follow a sentence that is said by
somebody and which the listeners have been told to repeat. It
means that the sentence should be said by whoever is saying it
twiee, with a pause each time after he says it, so that the listeners
can say it twice, too. We do not know whether this convention
should be continued in the final form of the script or whether
the sentence whould be written out twice for the actor to read,
with a pause indicated after each of the sentences. Probably the
VOA has some rule that would decide this question.
Having the scripts typed in Washington is complicating things
a little in one way—it is causing me to go back and clean up some
of my drafts so that the tyjist won't have to ask any questions.
Here I have not been too careful, because the typists could
always phone me. In some cases, as with lessoD 3, which I am
enclosing, it is simplest for me simply to type the script up,
but in other cases, to save time, I will submit it in manuscript,
as I have to the typists here.
I am enclosing only three scripts herewith, nos. 1, 2 & 3.
Margery has turned half a dozen more over to me, but I'm having to
go through them to make a few corrections—Britishisms, etc. I
expect to be able to send scripts 4 through 18 tomorrow.
I enclose a copy of tjiis letter for Dr. Goodell. Please
excuse the typing.
Sincerely,
